captions.text:
00:03
COMM: Big cat enthusiast Carl Bovard wakes

up every morning to wrestle with the eight
big cats in his backyard.

00:14
COMM: But living with such wild animals isn't
without it's risks.

00:19
CARL: Death would be the worst outcome. Instinctually

they just know to go for the vitals. I never
give them a free shot at my neck.

00:32
COMM: Nine years ago Carl set up Single Vision,

an educational non-profit organisation at
his home in Florida.

00:39
CARL: I think having these cats in captivity

and being able to show them off, it gives
people a chance to get a passion and an appreciation

for these animals. So I think it's essential
we have them in captivity to feed that passion
in people.

00:54
COMM: His biggest animal is seven hundred

pound Siberian tiger Samson, which towers
above him at over nine and a half feet tall.

01:01
CARL: There's just not many tigers bigger
than this one.

01:03
COMM: Each week Carl buys a massive fifteen

hundred pounds of meat, and the cats can devour
200lbs in a night.

01:12
CARL: Now here is where the relationship with

me and the cat does change, you can see he's
showing possessiveness. And I can't go up

and grab that food away from him now or even
a piece of it. You can see. And he's vocalising,

he's telling me and I'm not gonna push that
line.

01:29
COMM: Despite their killer instinct Kyle goes

out of his way to play rough with his huge
beasts.

01:35
CARL: When they're young and they're adolescents

they play really rough with each other in
the wild that's how they learn the skills

necessary to become efficient hunters and
we don't deny them that here.

01:46
COMM: But his hands-on approach comes with
it's own dangers.

01:50
CARL: I had a leopard bit me in the nose a

few years ago, had my nose sewed back together.
Injuries just are part of the job.

01:57
CARL: Big cats may have a fearsome reputation

but Carl is never short of people who want
to see what they can do.

02:03
COMM: Including volunteer Kia Spitzner.

02:06
KIA: In my friends group yeah I'm definitely

the crazy one, they call me the crazy cat
lady, something I love. I've never been nervous.

02:13
COMM: And the cats have even been socialised

to the point where they can live and play
together.

02:18
CARL: Here we have a tiger and a lion together

and in the wild they would never encounter
each other.

02:24
COMM: No stranger to the controversy surrounding
breeding big cats in captivity.

02:29
CARL: People that would say it's cruel to

keep large cats in captivity, most of the
people that say that say they should all be

in the wild, my question back to them is where
is the wild these days? We have over seven

billion people on the planet, they are destroying
the habitat where these guys live?

02:50
COMM: But his injuries or massive work load

have never stopped his love for big cats,
and his single vision dream to educated people
about the beasts.

02:57
CARL: I don't do this because it doesn't say

I guess I get that rush of adrenaline just
from being around them and working with them
and I can't imagine doing anything else.

comments.text:
What about their rights to be free? If you study Google Earth there is 
still significant terrain that is uninhabited. I respect that your have 
looked after and nurtured them to the age of self-sufficiency.  It is not 
about you.  I would not be surprised at all to hear a story about you being 
mauled.  It is time that they were released into the wild from captivity, 
there is still a remarkably sized playground for these cats to play in if 
you fund raise for their transportation into Africa. They pose a potential 
danger to you at this age and anyone that you live with or even visits. 
Utmost respect but they need to liberated.﻿

comments.author: omakshi pandey

comments.text:
Sorry, but you don´t know much about animals then. There were cases where 
dolphins killed their females by gang rape, and gang rapes are not unusual 
with dolphins. In the animal kingdom is a lot of bullying, wild and 
domestic animals do that, it´s not uncommon that the stronger one in a 
pack/herd injures or kills the weaker one. In general: If an animal senses 
that you´re weak 80% of the animals will walk all over you...and I´m 
talking about domestic animals. (horses & dogs do attack their owners, even 
if the owner was never bad to them..the owner is just unable to establish 
rules and has no self-confidence).

I do love animals and for 6 years I´m working with them (all kinds of 
domestic animals like horses, dogs, cats and some farm animals like cows, 
pigs ect.). I lost my naive thinking very fast. So, animals are not better 
than humans, but humans are no better than animals as well. Both have very 
beautfiul & unbelievable cruel sides.

+Rudy_Eila They actually have a contract with a grocery store that sells 
them close to expired meat that is no longer legal to sell for human 
consumption. The meat comes at a greatly reduced price, and helps to 
prevent wasting so much meat in today's society. That's how the majority of 
big cat sanctuaries are able to feed their animals.
comments.author: Lion Girl

comments.text:
Not really, on the "just have a good job" comment because there are only a 
handful of jobs in the world which will support that kind of expense. The 
story said they list themselves as a "non-profit education center," so 
besides whatever admission they charge, they don't pay taxes on that 
income-- you pay their taxes in forms of whatever gov. subsidies they get. 
That's how people live off shady "non-profits" of all kinds, which are 
rampant in Florida, by the way.

So a friend of mine is the kind of an idiot saying "they are wild animals 
that will kill you on the spot" so I sent him this saying, every animal can 
learn to tolerate you and accept you as long as you treat them with 
respect, even the biggest predators can become your best friends.

Sadly people dont realize that enough anymore, treat them exactly how you 
want to be treated by them and stop screaming about them being "locked in a 
cage/captivity". You can clearly see even in this video these animals are 
happy and healthy and in much less danger in his care rather than in the 
"wild" where they will be hunted for their pelts.﻿
